column1: # EWG Shopper's Guide to Pesticides in Produce (2025)
# Trust Level: Research Non-profit - Peer-reviewed methodology

column2: 692 samples of 47 fruits and vegetables (USDA PDP)

column1: #   - Testing: Produce washed and peeled (as consumers would) before testing
#   - 265 total pesticides and breakdown products identified
#   - 75%+ of non-organic produce had detectable pesticide residues
#   - 203 pesticides found on Dirty Dozen produce
#   - New 2025 entries: potatoes and blackberries (Dirty Dozen)
# Pesticide Residue Score: 1-100 scale (estimated from rank position)

column6: Thick skin protects fruit - lowest residue
Note: most Hawaiian papaya is GMO
Multiple protective layers shield from contamination
Grows quickly - less pesticide exposure time
Florets protected by thick outer leaves
Fuzzy skin typically peeled before eating
Rind not eaten but moderate residue on flesh
Edible pod exposes to moderate residue
Peel removed but some residue on flesh
Peel removed but residue can transfer
Husk offers some protection but moderate residue
Thin skin with moderate pesticide absorption
Thin edible skin with moderate residue
Outer leaves removed but inner still exposed
Often eaten with skin - moderate residue
Peel removed but residue can transfer
Delicate fruit with high pesticide levels
Imported grapes often have higher residues
High levels of DCPA and other pesticides
Over 90% of samples had detectable pesticides
